Americans have been nearly buried in polling data – most of it unreliable – and every other second, some new “expert” has spouted off on social media about how this or that “indicator” strongly favors one candidate or another.

It appears we, as a country, have traded patience for an addiction to a steady stream of hack prognostications that, in total, tells us nothing.

Throughout election season, there have been two options:

Do your thing, advocate for your preferred candidate, vote and then wait for the voting process to unfold, knowing it will happen before too long.

Constantly freak out over polls by pollsters you’ve never heard of and allow people whose only talent is being frequently wrong get in your head and make you feel anxious and wholly unwilling to … you know … just let the election happen and await the results.

It’s our wholly irrational demand to know the outcome before a vote is even cast that has birthed these dime-store Nostradamuses. And I, for one, look forward to them sinking into irrelevancy once the actual election outcome has been made clear.

The need for instant gratification is killing us, folks. And it's making a lot of otherwise useless people feel important.

— Rex Huppke, USA TODAY

If Trump loses, I hope Republicans send him and his election lies packing

Election week is a tumultuous time, particularly in recent years, as the legitimacy of our elections has been called into question almost entirely on no serious basis.

The 2020 election wasn’t the first contested election result in American history, but it was the most brazenly lied about one. Many Republicans still refuse to admit that they lost in 2020 out of their ridiculous loyalty to Donald Trump.

My only hope for this week, and maybe an unrealistic one, is that regardless of the winner, our politicians put the country over partisanship to admit that the race was a legitimate one.

This is naturally unlikely in the event of a Trump loss, given his response to his defeat in 2020. If Republicans truly cared about the state of America, they would be wise not to follow his lead in the event of a loss. They have the chance to act as they should have in 2020, jettisoning Trump and his election lies from the party, but they have given me no reason to think they might change.

— Dace Potas, USA TODAY

For Trump, win or lose, it's the end of an era

Former President Donald Trump celebrated the beginning of Election Day in Grand Rapids, Michigan – marking the third time he’s closed out his campaign in this city in a key battleground state.

Trump won Michigan in 2016 but lost it in 2020. He’s hoping for a repeat of his victory eight years ago.

Regardless of the outcome Tuesday, this final rally in Michigan also likely marks the final campaign rally for Trump – ever.

He seemed to acknowledge that in his remarks.

“This has been an incredible journey,” Trump told the crowd. “It’s very sad in a way. This is the last one.”

At 78, Trump has said that if he loses this election, he will not seek the presidency in 2028. If he wins a second term this week, he will be barred by the Constitution from seeking a third term in four years.

So, this is it. For nearly 10 years, his rallies have dominated the news cycle and have become a phenomenon that is uniquely tied to Trump’s brand.

And even though the media quickly moved on, let’s not forget that Trump nearly lost his life at one of his rallies this year.

I’ll never forget hearing the news about the July assassination attempt in Butler, Pennsylvania. It was a dark day for the country.

Yet, Trump’s immediate response – with a fist raised while blood ran down his face – is iconic.

No matter how you feel about the former president, the end of his campaign rallies marks the end of an era.

— Ingrid Jacques, USA TODAY

Could we have our first Black, woman president? Philadelphia mayor reflects.

PHILADELPHIA — Cherelle Parker took a long beat to consider the question on Election Day: Did she think, growing up, that she would ever see a Black and South Asian woman as president of the United States?

“No,” said Parker, a Black woman and Democrat now serving as Philadelphia’s first female mayor.

Parker is known for her projective oratory, her signature speeches always building to a crescendo designed to drive home her point. Her pause, followed by a soft-spoken “no,” showed just how personal this presidential election was for her.

“Representation matters,” Parker said, rolling again into a methodically upticking tempo in her response. “My grandmother was from Manning, South Carolina. All of the matriarchs in my family, when they got to Philadelphia, they were domestic workers. I know some people don't even know what a domestic worker is, but that means my grandmother was paid in cash, an envelope left on a table for her after she cleaned the houses of wealthy families while she was taking care of me, her granddaughter, who was born to a single teenage mother.”

Like Vice President Kamala Harris, the mayor graduated from a historically Black college and university.

Parker addressed about 30,000 people at Harris’ final campaign rally in Philadelphia on Monday evening, telling them, "The path to the White House is paved through Pennsylvania, the Keystone State.”

“When you look at her and you see her, you say, anything is possible,” Parker said Tuesday. “She's been prepared to meet this moment, and I'm telling you for generations to come, they will know I, too, can do that if it's what I decide to do. There are no limits.”

— Chris Brennan, USA TODAY

Will abortion ballot measures be a deciding factor in 2024?

Something I’ll pay close attention to as election results are reported is the impact of abortion in driving voters to the polls.

Expanding abortion rights was a key motivating issue in the 2022 midterm elections, especially for women, and helped Democrats minimize the anticipated Republican “red wave.”

In fact, in all the states where abortion has been on the ballot since Roe v. Wade was overturned by the U.S. Supreme Court in 2022, reproductive rights have prevailed. That’s been true in blue and red states, including Michigan and Ohio, which now have lenient abortion rights enshrined in their constitutions.

Ten states have similar measures on their ballots this election: Arizona, Colorado, Florida, Maryland, Missouri, Montana, Nebraska, Nevada, New York and South Dakota.

I’ll be watching Arizona and Florida most closely.

Arizona is a battleground state, and if abortion drives more women to the polls, it is likely to boost Vice President Kamala Harris, because women are much more likely to support the Democratic nominee.

If the abortion amendment clears the high hurdle of 60% support to pass in Florida – which has become a decidedly red state – that does not bode well for pro-life efforts in other states to stop similar expansion of abortion access.

This election is different, in that it is a presidential election year and former President Donald Trump is on the ballot. We’re also further removed from Roe being overturned.

Regardless, I expect abortion will still play a role.

— Ingrid Jacques, USA TODAY

What does canvassing mean in politics? All the difference on Election Day.

It’s Election Day, but the job of political canvassers is not yet done.

Canvassing has evolved from door-to-door conversations and phone banks to social media connections and digital coalitions. But it’s still a significant influencer in voter turnout and in swaying undecided voters.

According to volunteers, one of the great benefits of political canvassing is in-person voter engagement. Having a one-on-one conversation with an undecided voter may encourage them to learn more about the candidates running for office and could even persuade them to vote.

I spoke with an experienced canvasser, Lakesha Cole, founder and principal publicist at She Pr, about her work on political campaigns.

“Canvassing for Military Families for Kamala has been one of the most rewarding experiences of my adult life.” Cole said. “I grew up in a very civically involved family and can recall visiting the polls as a kid with my grandparents and walking around the neighborhoods with them, encouraging other neighbors to vote.”

In today’s political climate, where misinformation is rampant and trust in the government is low, canvassing provides an invaluable interpersonal connection that few other campaign strategies can replicate.

— Marla Bautista, USA TODAY

When will we get the election results? Pennsylvania governor dodges the question.

PHILADELPHIA — Two questions loomed over the lunch here as Democrats gathered to swap presidential Election Day gossip: Who will win Pennsylvania? And when will we know?

Gov. Josh Shapiro, a Democrat who made the short list for vice president candidate, was eager to describe a day of voting where Democrats and Republicans worked together in a bipartisan way to overcome technical troubles at polling places. He was far less eager to predict when Pennsylvania’s result would be announced.

“What we've seen since 2020 are clerks of elections learning how to do this job even better,” Shapiro said. “They’re more skilled. They've got better technology, more equipment and a whole lot more practice.”

He also noted that the use of mail ballots in Pennsylvania has significantly decreased since the 2020 election, held during the COVID-19 pandemic. Pressed for a prediction, Shapiro said this twice – “I think all that together should speed up the count.”

Sharif Street, a state senator from Philadelphia and chair of the Pennsylvania Democratic Party, was cautious to avoid speaking for election officials but more open to making a prediction. He said Pennsylvania’s result could be announced “by the end of the day Wednesday.”

“We want to get an accurate count,” Street said. “I think that's the most important thing.”

U.S. Rep. Brendan Boyle, a Democrat who represents parts of Philadelphia, said the timing of the result will be determined by the margin.

“Are we talking about a 1.2 (percentage point) race like it was in 2020, or are we talking about a 537-vote race, as it was in Florida in 2000?” Boyle said. “That's the last variable that will dictate whether or not we're able to know in the early morning hours on Wednesday or if it will go longer than that.”

— Chris Brennan, USA TODAY

If Harris loses, will Democrats complain about election integrity?

I hope we learned from the 2020 election that voting is secure in all 50 states. Nonetheless, state voting laws could influence election results this year.

On Wednesday, a majority of U.S. Supreme Court justices granted Virginia’s request to temporarily block an order that would have required the state to return about 1,600 people to the voter rolls.

The case involved Virginia’s efforts to revoke the voter registration of suspected noncitizens under a state law enacted in 2006. In August, Gov. Glenn Youngkin issued an executive order requiring the Department of Motor Vehicles to conduct daily checks of voter rolls to remove noncitizens.

The Biden administration argued that Youngkin’s order violates the “quiet period” provision of the National Voter Registration Act, which prohibits states from removing ineligible voters within 90 days of a federal election.

The dispute over Virginia’s voting rolls is just one example of recent integrity news stories across the country. From arson attacks on ballot boxes in Oregon and Washington state, to the Supreme Court’s decision Friday to allow Pennsylvania to count contested provisional ballots against Republicans’ wishes, election integrity claims could cast doubt on election results.

For the past four years, Democrats have claimed there are almost no election integrity issues in the United States. If Vice President Kamala Harris loses a close election and Democrats show concerns about election integrity, I’m calling their bluff now.

— Nicole Russell, USA TODAY

Gen Z appears to be voting in battleground states

For most of this year, I’ve been focused on what Generation Z, those born between 1997 and 2012, thinks about this election.

The Harris campaign, in particular, has done much work to reach Gen Z voters – and it appears to be paying off. Harris has a 51-point lead among college students in battleground states, according to a poll from The Generation Lab.

Outreach hasn’t stopped ahead of election night, either. The Gen Z advocacy group Voters of Tomorrow announced that it made 6 million direct contacts with young people over the weekend.

Meanwhile, the Access Hollywood tape is going viral on TikTok – introducing an entire new generation of young people to the vile comments Trump made in 2005.

Gen Z voters could very well decide this election. We’ll see if this pays off for Harris.

— Sara Pequeño, USA TODAY

In Wisconsin, epicenter of 2020 election denial, pro-democracy groups brace for the worst

MILWAUKEE — Wisconsin was an epicenter of election denialism in 2020. With Donald Trump repeating false claims he won the state throughout the 2024 campaign and the Republican Party training thousands of polling place observers, pro-democracy groups have braced for the worst.

As of noon central time, however, election monitors from Protect Democracy’s Wisconsin chapter said there have been minimal reports of issues at polling places.

“At this point, things are running pretty smoothly,” said Edgar Lin, an attorney and policy strategist with the group.

“There’s been scattered attempts at voter intimidation, people not knowing about Wisconsin’s voter ID laws.”

In July, police removed two election observers from a suburban Milwaukee polling place for being disruptive while objecting to ballots during a primary election. Lin said his group is most focused on voters being obstructed at polling places or frivolous ballot objections.

In a courtroom Tuesday morning, attorneys for the Republican Party walked back claims in a lawsuit filed Monday that its polling observers were being restricted at Milwaukee polling places.

“For today, what we’re looking at are disruptions that slow down the voting process and sow doubt about the election results or lead to false claims of victory,” Lin said.

— Jim Fitzhenry, Milwaukee Journal Sentinel

Joe Rogan endorsed Trump – the guy he once called a dangerous man baby

Bro-darling podcaster Joe Rogan – who once called Donald Trump “so f---ing dangerous,” a “man baby” and “a guy (who) can incite a bunch of morons to do something really f---ing stupid” – has now endorsed the dangerous man baby for president.

On the eve of Election Day, Rogan posted his support for the former one-term president and convicted felon on social media, effectively blaming that support on fellow bro-darling weirdo Elon Musk: “The great and powerful @elonmusk. If it wasn't for him we'd be f---ed. He makes what I think is the most compelling case for Trump you'll hear, and I agree with him every step of the way.”

Cool.

The fact that this happened, and more the fact that this matters, further illustrates that nothing makes sense anymore, and I should hasten my plans to go into the forest and live in a tree.

Rogan, Musk and Trump form a turducken of three people many Americans would love to hear less about, so it’s a perfect ménage à trois of ick in an era of near-boundless stupidity.

But here we are. If Rogan’s endorsement means something to you, congratulations. I have no response to that.

If you, like me, are exhausted by the buffoonery we’ve experienced throughout Trump’s campaign, you know what to do. Get out there and vote for the one who isn’t surrounded by buffoons.

— Rex Huppke, USA TODAY

Harris used pre-Election Day rally to remind voters of the dangers of Trump

PHILADELPHIA — Consider these words said at a historic location in this city to a massive rally crowd the day before a presidential election.

Donald Trump is “a loose cannon who could put everything at risk.” And “none of us want to wake up Wednesday morning and wish we’d done more.” Or “every issue you care about is on the ballot.”

Vice President Kamala Harris?

No, that was Hillary Clinton, speaking at her final campaign event on Independence Mall on the Monday evening before the 2016 election, before the former first lady, U.S. senator and secretary of State narrowly lost Pennsylvania and the presidency to Trump.

Harris came to Philadelphia on Monday for her own closing event on the iconic steps of the Philadelphia Museum of Art, a venue made famous by several “Rocky” movies. Harris spoke 2 miles northwest of where Clinton made her closing case eight years ago.

Harris drew an adoring throng of 30,000 supporters who remained through a chilly evening, listening to performances by The Roots, Ricky Martin and Lady Gaga before Oprah Winfrey introduced the Democratic presidential nominee.

It was designed to be hopeful, but there was an echo of anxiety for those who remember how Clinton seemed on the cusp of becoming America’s first female president before Trump surprised her (and himself) by eking out a victory here and the other “blue wall” states of Michigan and Wisconsin.

Harris and most of the speakers before her Monday night alluded to Trump and the dangers they see if he wins the presidency again.

“We have an opportunity in this election to finally turn the page on a decade of politics that has been driven by fear and division,” Harris told the crowd. “We are done with that. We’re done. We’re exhausted with it.”

— Chris Brennan, USA TODAY

North Carolina is still reeling from Helene, but Asheville residents make a point to vote

On Friday, I went to Asheville, North Carolina, to talk to voters who were affected by Hurricane Helene. One polling place I visited was still operating as a clean-water station, a donation drop-off spot and a place to get hot meals.

At another polling place, the Buncombe County Democrats had a large sign that read, “Stronger than storms, stronger than hate.”

Asheville is a blue dot in an otherwise red part of the state. Despite previous concerns about voter turnout, the 25 counties affected by Hurricane Helene had a 2% higher voter turnout during early voting than the rest of the state.

This can be attributed to the Buncombe County Board of Elections, which immediately worked to change polling places and voting hours to allow folks to vote.

“Asheville is politically strong in their beliefs,” voter EJ Wright told me. “It doesn’t matter if there was still floodwaters out here; I think people would still be out here trying to vote.”

— Sara Pequeño, USA TODAY

Too distressed to go to school because of the election? Snowflake culture is out of control.

An elite private school in New York City told families last week that students will be treated with kid gloves on Election Day.

No homework will be assigned Tuesday at the Ethical Culture Fieldston School, and the day after the election – or whenever the results become known – “students who feel too emotionally distressed” will be excused from class. Psychologists will be available to offer counseling.

The principal of the upper school (a fancy term for high school) told families that regardless of the outcome, the school will provide students with “the support they may need.”

What is this teaching kids? If anything, all the attention to the “anxiety” they may hypothetically experience is probably causing a lot more of it.

I’m guessing it’s the teachers and administrators at the school (and parents) who feel the most anxious about the presidential election, and they are transferring their feelings onto the students in their care.

The school is not alone in its coddling. I’ve heard of colleges planning “emotional support” following the election. News organizations, including The Washington Post, have offered advice about how to “survive” election anxiety and deal with “loss.”

It’s bad enough if adults can’t handle the “stress” of voting, but it’s more alarming to force that anxiety onto young people.

As comedian Jerry Seinfeld, whose children have attended Fieldston, told The New York Times: “What kind of lives have these people led that makes them think that this is the right way to handle young people? To encourage them to buckle.”

That’s definitely the wrong message to send.

— Ingrid Jacques, USA TODAY

Can we trust the polls? They were wrong in 2020 and 2016.

Political polls were once reliable indicators of electoral outcomes, but not anymore. In the 2016 presidential election, polls leading up to the election largely predicted a win for Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, only to be confounded by Donald Trump’s victory.

The results shocked the world and marked a major turning point in public trust in political polling. News outlets, pollsters and political analysts scrambled to analyze why the polls were wrong. The reasons cited ranged from underestimating rural turnout, changing voter behavior, sampling errors and problems with timing.

In 2020, the polls showed that Joe Biden had a 12-point lead over Trump. In reality, Biden won the election by about 4 percentage points.

The inaccuracies continued to diminish voters’ trust in the polls. Today, voters are less likely to respond to pollsters, producing even less data to analyze.

Even though polls aren’t as accurate predictors of the outcomes of elections as they once were, their impact remains substantial. Polls should be used to gauge sentiment and trends, not predict election outcomes.

If we’ve learned anything from the mishaps of 2016 and 2020, it’s that polling needs to be refined and its uses limited. Voter emotions and sentiments can shift leading up to Election Day, and while polls do offer insight, they are no longer the crystal balls they were once thought to be.

— Marla Bautista, USA TODAY

In Pennsylvania, Republicans started challenging votes before polls opened

The polls hadn’t even opened in Pennsylvania before local boards of election had to start fielding thousands of challenges to ballots cast by people living overseas.

The experts at Keep Our Republic, a nonpartisan nonprofit dedicated to protecting elections, discussed that in a media briefing Monday afternoon.

John Jones III, a former federal judge in Pennsylvania appointed by then-President George W. Bush, noted that a lawsuit filed by six Republican members of the U.S. House from Pennsylvania attempted the same maneuver last month before being struck down in federal court.

“Thousands of ballots have been challenged,” Jones said. “So election bureaus are going to have to go piecemeal through these and make a determination.”

Jones also predicted that the boards “will make pretty quick work of these and deny the challenges” because they tend to follow the same approach.

The gist of the argument: Claim that state election officials don't do enough to verify the identities of U.S. military service members and their spouses who vote while stationed in other countries.

U.S. District Judge Christopher Conner’s response last week – the members of Congress waited until too close to the election, didn’t have standing to sue and “failed to articulate a viable cause of action.”

— Chris Brennan, USA TODAY

search_result.text:
David Shepardson and Akash Sriram

Reuters

WASHINGTON — The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said Tuesday it has opened a probe into 2.6 million Tesla vehicles in the United States over reports of crashes involving a feature that allows users to move their cars remotely.

The new investigation comes after the U.S. auto safety agency in October opened an investigation into 2.4 million Tesla vehicles equipped with Full Self-Driving software after four reported collisions, including a fatal 2023 crash.

NHTSA said it is opening a preliminary evaluation into Tesla's Actually Smart Summon feature over reports of four crashes involving Tesla vehicles.

The vehicles failed to detect posts or parked vehicles when they were operating on Actually Smart Summon, NHTSA said, adding it had reports where users "had too little reaction time to avoid a crash, either with the available line of sight or releasing the phone app button, which stops the vehicle's movement."

Actually Smart Summon was launched in September and allows users to remotely move their vehicle toward them or to another location using a smartphone application.

Need a break? Play the USA TODAY Daily Crossword Puzzle.

The predecessor to the feature allowed users to move their car forward or backward into or out of a parking spot.

NHTSA is opening a preliminary evaluation into the feature and then must decide whether to update the probe to an engineering analysis before it could seek to require a recall.

President-elect Donald Trump will take office in 13 days and Tesla CEO Elon Musk is a close adviser who has previously criticized NHTSA's actions.

NHTSA said it will assess Actually Smart Summon's maximum speed, use on public roads and line of sight requirements. The probe will also cover remote control through the phone app, the impact of connectivity delays and the system's performance in unanticipated conditions.

The probe covers 2016-25 Model S and X vehicles, 2017-25 Model 3 and 2020-25 Model Y with the optional Full Self-Driving driver assistance system.

Tesla, whose stock was down 1.9% in trading before the bell, did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Tesla in December 2023 recalled more than 2 million U.S. vehicles to install new safeguards in its Autopilot advanced driver-assistance system. NHTSA is still probing whether that recall is adequate to address concerns drivers are not paying attention.

The heightened scrutiny of the advanced driver assistance system comes as Musk looks to pivot toward self-driving technology and robotaxis.

search_result.title: Hallmark Channel Christmas movies: What's new on schedule this ...
search_result.text:
Hallmark Channel's Countdown to Christmas has already begun and this year it's packed with plenty of new holiday movies to binge for hours — or days.

You'll see appearances from a lot of familiar faces like Candace Cameron Bure and Tamera Mowry-Housley. There's also a double serving of real life sisters Kimberly Williams-Paisley and Ashley Williams in two "Sister Swap" movies.

Here's a guide to the new movies premiering this year. You can check out the full schedule on the Hallmark Channel website.

'Nantucket Noel'

Christina is a toy store owner who inherited the shop on the Nantucket wharf from her mom, who recently passed away, and she is having a hard time moving on. Andy is a confident, driven, real estate developer who is visiting his father on Nantucket with his young daughter Wink. Christina is dismayed when she learns Andy and his father plan to redevelop the wharf into a new marina. If this happens, she may have to give up the toy store that has such deep personal meaning and is part of her family’s legacy. Christina also discovers she has feelings for Andy but being on opposite sides of the development project could nip their romance in the bud.

Cast: Sarah Power (“Good Witch”), Trevor Donovan (“90210”) and Payton Lepinski

When to watch: Premieres 8 p.m. Nov. 19

'A Very Merry Bridesmaid'

Leah’s 30th birthday is Christmas Eve but this milestone takes a back seat when her future sister-in-law claims Christmas Eve for her wedding and asks Leah to be one of the many bridesmaids. But the return of Leah’s childhood crush Drew may be exactly what she needs to push her to the forefront of the overlapping festivities and determine a new direction in her life.

Cast: Emily Osment (“The Kominsky Method”) and Casey Deidrick (“Days of Our Lives”)

When to watch: Premieres 8 p.m. Dec. 4

'Making Spirits Bright'

Grace Ryan, the co-owner of a Richmond-based home staging company, returns to her hometown to be with her family for the Christmas holiday. The Ryans, seasonal holiday decorators, are competing in the annual Bright Nights contest for the opportunity to not only secure a lucrative contract to decorate every municipal building in town next season, but also a substantial cash prize. With Grace’s father’s furniture business on the ropes financially, this prize could turn his fortunes around. But they will have to compete against Mr. Ryan’s ex-business partner-turned-arch-nemesis Frank Sotto and his family, as well as a tech-heavy newcomer. As Grace reunites with her childhood friend, Tony Sotta, Frank’s handsome son, they realize the only chance the families have to defeat the new tech-heavy company is to team up. Can the two families put aside their differences to work together towards a common goal, and possibly mend a decadesold feud?

Cast: Taylor Cole (“Ruby Herring Mysteries”), Carlo Marks (“Chesapeake Shores”), Garry Chalk (“Beast Machines: Transformers”) and John Cassini (“Next”)

When to watch: Premieres 6 p.m. Nov. 27

'A Christmas Together With You'

When widower Frank finds a picture of his first love, Claire, his young friend Megan, proprietor of the cafe he frequents, convinces him to go on a road trip to track her down. Though reluctant, Frank agrees to the trip when he sees that it might help Megan recover from her recently broken engagement. The two set off on their adventure and find themselves opening up to each other. Along the way, Megan has an awkward run-in with a man and his dog that she can’t seem to shake off. The pair soon arrive at Claire’s address only to find the home vacant. Not deterred from their search, they stay at a nearby lodge where a surreptitious clue ultimately leads the pair to Claire. However, when they don’t get the reception they expected, the story of how Frank’s first love ended slowly reveals itself. Meanwhile, Megan learns that the man she’d met earlier, Steve, is the lodge’s owner. She helps him with some of his holiday responsibilities and they soon warm to each other and find that they are each grappling with their hopes for the future. As Megan helps Frank pursue a second chance at love and he reminds her not to give up on her dreams or her heart, these unlikely friends find that sometimes the closest family is the kind we make.

Cast: Laura Vandervoort (“Smallville”), Niall Matter (“Eureka”), Harry Lennix ("Batman v. Superman", "The Blacklist") and Liza Huget (“Motherland: Fort Salem”)

When to watch: Premieres 8 p.m. Nov. 20

'The Christmas Contest'

Business consultant, Lara and retired baseball star, Ben learn that their local Denver television station is hosting a Christmas contest with a cash prize for a charity of the winner’s choosing, they seize the challenge. Lara is playing for the local senior center that her mom, Donna attends, which is badly in need of repairs. Ben claims that he’s in the contest to help a local youth sports team but might be more interested in the press it could bring for his failing career. On the first day of competition, they both show up not realizing the other is about to compete. Lara and Ben previously dated, and the relationship didn’t end well. As the contest heats up with Christmas-themed challenges, our competitors realize they have far more in common than their love of Christmas. Now, Lara and Ben must decide what’s more important, winning the contest or finding true love.

Cast: Candace Cameron Bure (“Fuller House,” ”Aurora

Teagarden Mysteries”), John Brotherton (“Fuller House”) and Barbara Niven (“Chesapeake Shores”)

When to watch: Premieres 8 p.m. Nov. 28

'Sister Swap: A Hometown Holiday'

Jennifer and Meg Swift are sisters who couldn’t be closer despite living in different cities. Jennifer runs a successful restaurant in Salt Lake City, which she started with her late husband and is raising her teenage son Simon on her own. Jennifer is thrilled when Meg comes to Salt Lake City for a fun Christmas weekend. Meg agrees to stay in the city and help out at the restaurant while Jennifer and Simon return home to Hazelwood for the holiday, where they become wistful for one more Christmas at The Madison — the local movie theater owned by their Uncle Dave. The trouble is the theater is for sale and in need of repairs. With help from Eric, Jennifer’s former high school debate team rival, and the community, they just might pull off one last encore. As she and Eric

work together, Jennifer is reminded that new possibilities are both where you least expect them and exactly where you left them.

Cast: Kimberly Williams-Paisley (“Darrow Mysteries,” Father of the Bride), Ashley Williams (“Never Kiss a Man in a Christmas Sweater,” “The Jim Gaffigan Show”), Mark Deklin (“Grace and Frankie,” “Designated Survivor”), Susan Yeagley (“Mike Tyson Mysteries,” “Parks and Recreation”), Kevin Nealon ("Saturday Night Live," “Man with a Plan,” “Weeds”), Keith Robinson (“Redemption in Cherry Springs,” “Saints and Sinners”) and Jacob Buster (“Colony”)

When to watch: Premieres 8 p.m. Dec. 5

'Sister Swap: Christmas in the City'

Jennifer and Meg Swift are sisters who couldn’t be closer despite living in different cities. Meg comes to Salt Lake City from her hometown in Hazelwood to see her sister Jennifer, who runs a local restaurant in town. Still feeling the effects of losing their Uncle Dave, a change of scenery and a project to dive into are just what she needs. When Jennifer and her teenage son, Simon, return to Hazelwood home for a pre-holiday visit with their family, Meg offers to help Jennifer’s staff prepare for a competition among local restaurants that awards the winner money for the charity of its choice. As effusive Meg works alongside the more reserved Joe, the restaurant’s manager, the two find their differences are what make them a great team. Swapping cities with her sister leads Meg to her next chapter and just might also bring her an unexpected romance.

Cast: Ashley Williams (“Never Kiss a Man in a Christmas Sweater,” “The Jim Gaffigan Show”), Kimberly Williams-Paisley (“Darrow Mysteries,” "Father of the Bride"), Keith Robinson (“Redemption in Cherry Springs,” “Saints and Sinners”), Kevin Nealon ("Saturday Night Live," “Man with a Plan,” “Weeds”) and Jacob Buster, ("Colony")

When to watch: Premieres 8 p.m. Dec. 12

'A Kiss Before Christmas'

Real estate development executive Ethan Holt is a married father with two teens. On Christmas Eve, Ethan is disappointed to learn he’s losing out on a promotion and laments that his “nice guy” way of doing business has held him back in his career. Thanks to some Christmas magic, Ethan’s casual wish that his life had taken a different course becomes reality. He wakes up the next morning and is shocked to find everything is different — he isn’t married to Joyce, he doesn’t have two teenaged kids and he’s CEO of his company. Joyce is the key to Ethan being able to reclaim his original life and the family he loves — he must convince her that their happily-ever-after is waiting for them …and he only has until Christmas Day.

Cast: James Denton ("Desperate Housewives") and Teri Hatcher ("Desperate Housewives")

When to watch: Premieres 8 p.m. Nov. 21

'A Holiday in Harlem'

After her grandmother, Mama Belle, turns away her usual gift delivery, expecting “presence over presents,” jet-setting executive Jazmin heads uptown to Harlem for a quick visit. However, when Mama Belle is injured, Jazmin agrees to stay in the neighborhood and take over co-chairing their block’s annual Christmas Jamboree with her old best friend Caleb. A successful corporate fixer, Jazmin expects the job to be easy but quickly finds that she has a lot to learn about the community and her heart.

Cast: Olivia Washington (“Mr. Robot,” "The Little Things"), Will Adams (“The Oval”) and Tina Lifford (“Queen Sugar,” "Babe")

When to watch: Premiered Nov. 14

'My Family Christmas Tree'

Vanessa has never had a real family to celebrate with during the holidays, but when she receives the results from her family tree DNA test, she discovers a family she didn’t know existed. Richard, her biological father, invites her to spend the Christmas weekend with him and his family. Richard asks a family friend, Kris, who joins them every Christmas, to pick her up on his way. Kris knows all the details of her new family and helps break the ice when she meets Richard’s wife and their three children for the first time. It’s a bit uncomfortable at first but the family takes part in their Christmas traditions. As the weekend progresses, Vanessa meets her grandmother and other relatives, and even helps her little sister overcome stage fright before performing at the Christmas pageant. Vanessa is having a wonderful time getting to know her new family until she gets a message from the DNA testing company with some surprising news that she worries may jeopardize her holiday.

Cast: Aimee Teegarden (“Once Upon a Christmas Miracle,” “Friday Night Lights”), Andrew Walker (“The 27-Hour Day,” “Christmas Tree Lane”) and James Tupper (“Big Little Lies,” “Revenge”)

When to watch: Premiered Nov. 13

'Open By Christmas'

While helping her parents move, Nicky discovers a card given to her in high school that she never knew existed. In it, a secret admirer confides their true emotions. With the support of her lifelong best friend Simone, Nicky embarks on a quest to find and thank the anonymous author. Meanwhile, Simone is a working, single mother who feels like she’s losing touch with her teenage son, especially as she plans to marry again and start a new chapter in life.
